objects.name: XML External Entity (XXE) processing
objects.description: XML Parser allows XML External Entities inside SAML Messages and is wrongly configured to enable large XML document consumption.

external_references.url: https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities regarding a missing or an improper validation of the XML message that may hide malicious content

objects.name: Mitigations for XML External Entity (XXE) processing
objects.description:
In order to tackle this vulnerability, the XML Parser has to:
be implemented and updated using the latest version of the XML Library
be configured to disallow external general entities and external parameter entities features
raise an exception and stop parsing whenever XML forbidden characters (“&”, “<”, “>”) are found in the accessed file

Furthermore, these are the measures to mitigate the effects of the attacks:
the use of inline DTDs should be disabled in the XML parser code or ignoring external DTD files for DoS attacks
XML parser should provide a request timeout to prevent endless delay attack
XML parser can retrieve a limited amount of data
XmlResolver must not retrieve resources on the local host
A URI whitelist can be set to restrict the possible external url

external_references.url: https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Exponential entity expansion using parameter entities
objects.description:
An external entity is declared and a reference is made to a maliciously large file on a network resource (http://www.attacker.com/some.xml) or locally (file:///dev/random or file://c:/con/con).
Contents of the external file will be embedded into the XML document. The attack will perform a DoS crashing a web server (on a unix system).

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: DOS via XInclude
objects.description:
This attack uses an element containing the reference namespace for XInclude, an element with that namespace and an href attribute pointing to a malicious large local file. 

The attack will perform a DoS crashing a web server (on a unix system) or TCP scan.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Classic XXE variant 1.
objects.description:
The attack leverages external entity references in order to embed the content of different file into the XML document. 
This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Classic XXE attack using netdoc variant
objects.description:
The attack uses Netdoc as a protocol to embed content from different file into the XML document.
Netdoc is a URI scheme and it’s based on Oracle’s Java virtual machine.
This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Classic XXE using UTF-16 variant
objects.description:
The attack variant is based on changing the XML encoding from UTF-8 to UTF-16 in order to embed data which are located outside the main file into the XML document.
This attack evades blacklisting countermeasures enabling the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Classic XXE using UTF-7 variant
objects.description:
The attack variant is based on changing the XML encoding from UTF-7 to UTF-16 in order to embed data which are located outside the main file into the XML document.
This attack evades blacklisting countermeasures enabling the acquisition of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - Bypassing XXE restrictions variant 1.
objects.description:
The attack utilizes parameter entities to wrap content in a CDATA escape: the wrapped external entity includes the content of the target document. Another external entity points to an external .dtd file which contains only references to the parameters entities wrapping the content. 
This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - Bypassing XXE restrictions variant 2.
objects.description:
In this attack the external entity and the contained parameter entities which wrap the target content are defined in a payload.dtd file hosted on the attacker’s server. An entity reference of the main XML file allows the inclusion of external document’s content through those external entities.
This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - XXE by abusing attribute values variant
objects.description:
The attack consists in having an element root that contains an attribute whose value is a reference to a general entity which is declared by the value of a parameter entity on another .dtd file. The value of the above general entity is a parameter entity reference to another parameter entity whose value is the target file.



This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - XXE Out Of Band variant 1
objects.description:
The DTD file forces the XML parser to echo the content of a target file and to assign it to an entity. Then it will create a reference to that entity containing the content of the target file. 
This attack enables the acquisition of the content of target secret files and of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - XXE Out Of Band variant 2
objects.description:
DTD file contains a XXE injection that sends the contents of the /etc/password file to the web server of the tester.
The attack is executed by referencing the hosted DTD file and creating a connection to load that external DTD file. 
The hosted DTD file then uses parameter entities to wrap the contents of the /etc/passwd file into another HTTP request to tester.com.
It’s now possible to extract the contents of /etc/passwd file by reading incoming traffic on tester.com. The file contents can be parsed from web server logs or from an actual page.


this attack sends the content of the password file to another server

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - XXE Out Of Band variant 3
objects.description:
This attack variant utilizes a ftp request instead of creating an http request in order to perform the same attack as the variant 2
this attack sends the content of the password file to another server so that an attacker can read arbitrary files of any length using the FTP protocol

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - File-not-found exception variant
objects.description:
In this attack the data extraction is performed by forcing an error on the server through the addition of an invalid URI to the request.
If the server displays verbose errors to the client, the error may contain the file contents of the file that’s getting extracted.
This attack allows to read the content of a file through an error message displayed by a server

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - SchemaEntity via schemaLocation variant
objects.description:
The attack consists in a declaration of an external parameter entity “remote” with a URL resource as literal entity value, a reference of the external parameter entity “remote” and a declaration of an element “data” with a namespace xsi for XML-Schema and the attribute xsi:schemaLocation. The value of xsi:schemaLoation points to a server and the URL contains a reference to an internal general entity.
The parser invokes a URL request and the contents of the file are transmitted to the attacker.
This attack misuses XSD attribute schemaLocation to send arbitrary sensitive file content to a server.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - SchemaEntity via noNamespaceSchemaLocation variant
objects.description:
The attack consists in a declaration of an external parameter entity “remote” with a URL resource as literal entity value, a reference of the external parameter entity “remote” and a declaration of an element “data” with a namespace xsi for XML-Schema and the attribute xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation. The value of xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation points to a server and the URL contains a reference to an internal general entity.
The parser invokes a URL request and the contents of the file are transmitted to the attacker.
This attack misuse XSD attribute noNamespaceSchemaLocation to send arbitrary sensitive file content to a server.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Advanced XXE attack - SchemaEntity via XInclude variant
objects.description:
The attack consists in a declaration of an external parameter entity “remote” with a URL resource as literal entity value, a referencing of the external parameter entity “remote” and a declaration of an element “data” with a namespace xsi for XML-Schema and the attribute xsi:XInclude. The value of xsi:XInclude points to a server and the URL contains a reference to an internal general entity.
The parser invokes a URL request and the contents of the file are transmitted to the attacker. XInclude differs from XXE as an effective inclusion mechanism because of several unrestricted and convenient implications some of which include no need for well formedness and provision that allows content from other XML or non-XML text files in one XML document.
This attack misuse XSD attribute XInclude to send arbitrary sensitive file content to a server.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via XXE - XXE SSRF via external general entities variant
objects.description:
This attack is performed by creating inside a doctype an external entity whose value is a path to a target file and with a reference to that external entity in order to include its content in the XML document
This attack is used to perform SSRF attacks at the vulnerable IdP so it can make possible reading application data and execute unauthorized code or commands

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via XXE - XXE SSRF via external parameter entities variant
objects.description:
Given that the parameter entities are not subjected to constraints of well-formedness (like external general entities), they are used to enable SSRF attacks by creating requests to internal network from web-server parsing XML document in such a way to bypass the perimeter protection.
This attack is used to perform SSRF attacks at the vulnerable IdP so it can make possible reading application data and execute unauthorized code or commands

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via XXE - XXE SSRF via schemaLocation variant
objects.description:
The schemaLocation enables SSRF attacks by creating requests to internal network from web-server parsing XML document using the namespace SchemaLocation in such a way to bypass the perimeter protection. 
This attack is used to perform SSRF attacks at the vulnerable IdP so it can make possible reading application data and execute unauthorized code or commands

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via XXE - XXE SSRF via noNamespaceSchemaLocation variant
objects.description:
The noNamespaceSchemaLocation attribute enables SSRF attacks by creating requests to internal network from web-server parsing XML document in such a way to bypass the perimeter protection.
This attack is used to perform SSRF attacks at the vulnerable IdP so it can make possible reading application data and execute unauthorized code or commands

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via XXE - XXE SSRF via XInclude variant
objects.description:
The attack consists in inserting an internal URL related to a file as a value of the attribute href in the xi:include element inside of a related element.
This attack is used to perform SSRF attacks at the vulnerable IdP so it can make possible reading application data and execute unauthorized code or commands

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: TCP Scans
objects.description:
The attack consists in inserting an internal URL related to a file as a value of the attribute href in the xi:include element.
This attack is used as a reconnaissance technique to discover which services listen at well-known available ports to break in. In such a way the hacker finds potential weaknesses which can be exploited and may also be able to fool stateful firewalls into opening up access to additional TCP/UDP services with the network, though this is only plausible under very specific conditions.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Local file read/write
objects.description:
The XSLT transformation (Extensible Stylesheet Language Transformation(XSLT for short)) is executed before verification of the digital signature because it’s allowed by the XML Signature standard. The attack consists in preparing a SAML token t and creating an XML Signature for it which is not necessary to be correctly computed but inserted in a well-formed XML document. Then a Transform element is added to the XML Signature and a XSLT Payload is placed in it. This payload has the path of the targeted file as an attribute of the element <xsl:value-of>. 
Attacker will be able to read/write file Server side. XSLT can be used to read or write files locally which can then be sent over the internet.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: XML External Entity (XXE) processing
objects.description: XML Parser allows XML External Entities inside SAML Messages and is wrongly configured to enable large XML document consumption.

external_references.url: https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities regarding a missing or an improper validation of the XML message that may hide malicious content

objects.name: Sensitive File Disclosure via Classic XXE  using UTF-7 variant
objects.description:
The attack variant is based on changing the XML encoding from UTF-7 to UTF-16 in order to embed data which are located outside the main file into the XML document.
This attack evades blacklisting countermeasures enabling the acquisition of system specific informations about a website including software distribution, version numbers, patch levels, location of backup files or temporary files

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Unspecified XML entity expansion limit
objects.description: The XML Parser is incorrectly configured in such a way that it does not specify a limit on the number of entity substitutions.

external_references.url: http://www.ws-attacks.org/XML_Entity_Expansion

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities regarding a missing or an improper validation of the XML message that may hide malicious content

objects.name: Mitigations for Unspecified XML entity expansion limit
objects.description:
To deal with this vulnerability there exist some countermeasures differentiated per effectiveness:
turning off the entity expansion feature 
limit the number of entity substitutions
limiting the number of characters that entities can expand to
limiting the nesting depth of entities

external_references.url: http://www.ws-attacks.org/XML_Entity_Expansion

objects.name: Exponential entity expansion attack (billion laugh)
objects.description:
A lot of nested entities are defined within an XML DOCTYPE declaration, which can be easily exploited by an attacker to construct a memory bomb
cause the parser to generate an increasingly expanding payload, resulting into the consumption of significant memory space and in the end to a denial of service.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Unspecified XML entity expansion limit
objects.description: The XML Parser is incorrectly configured in such a way that it does not specify a limit on the number of entity substitutions.

external_references.url: http://www.ws-attacks.org/XML_Entity_Expansion

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities regarding a missing or an improper validation of the XML message that may hide malicious content

objects.name: Quadratic blowup attack
objects.description:
The attack consists in defining one single large entity and to refer to it many times. Basically, an entity “&a;” with a significant length of characters, say 100,000 long, refers to “&a;” 100,000 times inside the root element
This attack disrupt the parsing process of a Provider.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Missing check on canonicalization form
objects.description:
This vulnerability is caused by an unexpected behavior of XML libraries dealing with management of the comments in an XML Document. There are 2 critical aspects to consider: 
XML canonicalization: makes the signature validated even if an addition of comments to the SAMLResponse occurs 
XML text extraction: returns only a substring of the text within an XML element when comments are present 
The canonicalization method is applied to XML elements prior to signing so that multiple different-but-similar XML documents can have the same exact signature.

external_references.url: https://duo.com/blog/duo-finds-saml-vulnerabilities-affecting-multiple-implementations

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities regarding a missing or an improper validation of the XML message that may hide malicious content

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on canonicalization form
objects.description: A Remediation is to ensure that the default canonicalization algorithm is http://www.w3.org/2001/10/xml-exc-c14n#WithComments which does not omit comments during canonicalization and so invalidates the signature whether they are inserted.

external_references.url: https://duo.com/blog/duo-finds-saml-vulnerabilities-affecting-multiple-implementations

objects.name: Canolicalization attack
objects.description:
This attack consists in inserting comments into the value of NameID element of the attacker’s assertion so that the XML document still has the same signature but another user (the victim) is going to be authenticated. 

An attacker can authenticate as a different user with our knowledge of the victim users’ password.

external_references.url: XXE Cheat Sheet; https://web-in-security.blogspot.it/2016/03/xxe-cheat-sheet.html | Owasp XML External Entity; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing

objects.name: Missing end-to-end authentication between C and SP using Cookies
objects.description: Missing establishment of a secret validation token in the HTTP Request to determine, in the following steps of the Authentication Phase, whether the request comes from an authorized source.

external_references.description: Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations”
Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery”

external_references.url: https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to missing implementation of proper protection measures to avoid CSRF

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing end-to-end authentication between C and SP using Cookies
objects.description:
The SP has to set a cookie while creating the SAML Request and then has to expect to receive it back from the authorized C with the Response.
[1] proposes to design the secret token with cookie name = “hash value of the requested URI”, cookie value = “URI value” and then RelayState=“cookie name”.
Other more secure and sophisticated design solutions are proposed by [4.1 of 2]

external_references.description: Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations”
Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery”

external_references.url: https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP - Delivery of unrequested resource variant
objects.description:
C initiates the protocol by requesting a resource BadURI at BadSP
BadSP, pretending to be C, requests a different resource URI at another target SP.
SP generates, following the standard, an Authentication Request which is returned to BadSP.
BadSP replies maliciously to C by sending an HTTP-redirect-response to IdP containing an Authentication Request with the ID, SP and URI of the Request generated by SP, instead of the Request with the fields related to original request of the user.
The IdP authenticates the user though an authentication challenge
The attack makes C consume a resource from SP, while C originally asked for a different resource at BadSP.


The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

external_references.url: Research Paper 1; Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations” | Research Paper 2; Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP -  CSRF attack variant
objects.description:
C initiates the protocol by requesting a resource BadURI at BadSP
BadSP, pretending to be C, requests a different resource URI at another target SP.
SP generates, following the standard, an Authentication Request which is returned to BadSP.
BadSP replies maliciously to C by sending an HTTP-redirect-response to IdP containing an Authentication Request with the ID, SP and URI of the Request generated by SP, instead of the Request with the fields related to original request of the user.
The IdP authenticates the user though an authentication challenge
The attack makes C consume a URL-encoded command that performs an undesired action.


The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

external_references.url: Research Paper 1; Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations” | Research Paper 2; Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP -  Login CSRF attack variant
objects.description:
The attacker authenticates himself with his credentials through the SAML authentication phase for a specific resource
Then, the attacker makes the victim send a HTTP request containing its credentials to the authentication end point of a web site.
Receiving the forged request, the website will authenticate the victim as the attacker

The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

external_references.url: Research Paper 1; Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations” | Research Paper 2; Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP -  XSS attack variant
objects.description:
C initiates the protocol by requesting a resource BadURI at BadSP
BadSP, pretending to be C, requests a different resource URI at another target SP.
SP generates, following the standard, an Authentication Request which is returned to BadSP.
BadSP replies maliciously to C by sending an HTTP-redirect-response to IdP containing an Authentication Request with the ID, SP and URI of the Request generated by SP, instead of the Request with the fields related to original request of the user.
The IdP authenticates the user though an authentication challenge
The attack makes C execute malicious code as XXS attack
The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

external_references.url: Research Paper 1; Alessandro Armando, Roberto Carbone, Luca Compagna, Jorge Cuellar, Giancarlo Pellegrino, Alessandro Sorniotti - “An Authentication Flaw in Browser-based Single Sign-On Protocols/ Impact and Remediations” | Research Paper 2; Adam Barth, Collin Jackson, John C. Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP -  XSS for User Impersonation variant
objects.description:
C initiates the protocol by requesting a resource BadURI at BadSP
BadSP, pretending to be C, requests a different resource URI at another target SP.
SP generates, following the standard, an Authentication Request which is returned to BadSP.
BadSP replies maliciously to C by sending an HTTP-redirect-response to IdP containing an Authentication Request with the ID, SP and URI of the Request generated by SP, instead of the Request with the fields related to original request of the user.
The IdP authenticates the user though an authentication challenge
The attack makes C consume the URI javascript:window.open(‘uri(i)’+document.cookie) that will make the client victim of theft of its cookies for the domain sp
The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to missing implementation of proper protection measures to avoid CSRF

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing integrity protection of RelayState
objects.description:
The IdP must implements sanitization mechanism on the URL in order to 
-) allow URL schemes limited to “https” and “http”  
-)  disallow uncoded characters that may be used to mount XSS or CSRF attacks.

external_references.url: https://issues.oasis-open.org/browse/SECURITY-12
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Malicious resource provision by Intruder SP -  Delivery of unrequested resource variant
objects.description:
C initiates the protocol by requesting a resource BadURI at BadSP
BadSP, pretending to be C, requests a different resource URI at another target SP.
SP generates, following the standard, an Authentication Request which is returned to BadSP.
BadSP replies maliciously to C by sending an HTTP-redirect-response to IdP containing an Authentication Request with the ID, SP and URI of the Request generated by SP, instead of the Request with the fields related to original request of the user.
The IdP authenticates the user though an authentication challenge
The attack makes C consume a resource from SP, while C originally asked for a different resource at BadSP.


The attacker may be able to perform any unwanted action and even harming the entire application if it is able to do exploits on behalf of administrator users.

Mitchell - “Robust Defenses for Cross-Site Request Forgery” | CSRF Cheat Sheet; https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

objects.name: Missing check on the Recipient in Assertion
objects.description: No verification whether the value of the Recipient attribute actually matches with the SP’s assertion consumer service URL to which the Response was delivered.
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the Recipient in Assertion
objects.description:
The SP must check whether the value associated to the Recipient parameter in the SAMLResponse matches with the host name and path of its Assertion Consumer Service. 
If it does not, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: User Impersonation through dishonest SP on a target SP
objects.description:
A user initiates a session of the protocol to access a resource provided by the malicious SP “Intruder”
In parallel, SP “Intruder” starts a new session of the protocol with a target SP pretending to be the user. It reuses the same authentication assertion received to make the target SP believing that he is the user.
The attack terminates with the SP "Intruder” receiving the resource which should be reserved to user.
Only the users of the malicious SP Intruder can be victims of this attack.
Without knowing or guessing any credentials, the attacker has access to a resource of its desire available only to the victim, performs an action to which only the victim has a proper authorization or login as the victim at the target SP.

external_references.url: SAML specification; SAML Profiles - 3.3

objects.name: Missing check on Audience in Assertion
objects.description: No verification whether the SP is actually member of the domain indicated in the Audience element of the Assertion
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on Audience in Assertion
objects.description: The SP must check whether the value associated to the Audience element in the AudienceRestrictionType matches with the host name and path of its Assertion Consumer Service. If it does not, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: Missing check on Destination in Response
objects.description: Missing check whether, if present, the URI reference value of the Destination element identifies the SP to which the message was sent
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on Destination in Response
objects.description: The SP must check that the value of the Destination identifies the location at which the message was received. If it does not, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: Missing check on the InResponseTo element
objects.description: No verification whether the value of the InResponseTo attribute matches with the ID of the AuthnRequest at the beginning of the Authentication Phase.
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the InResponseTo element
objects.description: The SP checks whether the value of the InResponseTo matches with the AuthnRequest’s ID saved in the session by the SP. If it does not, then the SP has to reject the Response. After the validity time of the Response, the SP has to clear from the cache the ID values of the AuthnRequest and Response of the session

objects.name: Expired SAMLResponse Replay Attack
objects.description:
As a registered user, the attacker sends a valid Response to the SP.
Once the attacker has received the requested resource, it sends the Response or the Assertion again within the valid lifetime to the same SP
The attack is performed successfully whenever the SP provides the requested resource for the second time.
This attack can be easily performed by having access to any valid SAMLResponse as registered user.
The attacker can perform authorized actions or access resources twice without being properly authenticated as required by a SP in the second time.
Combined with “Missing end-to-end authentication between C and SP using Cookies”, the attacker can intercept an already consumed SAMLResponse and reuse it to have access to the resource of requested by the victim, performs an action to which only the victim has a proper authorization or login as the victim at a target SP. It is possible to reuse the Authentication Assertion in order to gain access or perform any action described in the SAML message without a proper authentication decision made by the IdP

external_references.url: SAML specification; SAML Profiles - 3.3

objects.name: Missing check on the NotOnOrAfter in Assertion
objects.description: No verification whether the validity period of time of the Response is respected.
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the NotOnOrAfter in Assertion
objects.description: The SP must check whether the validity of the Response is respected. If it does not, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: Missing check on the OneTimeUse element in Conditions element of Assertion
objects.description: No verification whether the Assertion has already been consumed.
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the OneTimeUse element in Conditions element of Assertion
objects.description: The SP must check whether the Response has been already consumed. If it does, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: Missing check on the AuthnContextClassRef element
objects.description: No verification whether the value of the AuthnContextClassRef contained in the Assertion matches with the value of the related sub-element AuthnContextClassRef of the RequestedAuthnContext.
objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the AuthnContextClassRef element
objects.description: The SP must check whether the value of AuthnContextClassRef of the Assertion matches with the value of the AuthnContextClassRef of the AuthnRequest. If it does not, the request MUST be discarded.

objects.name: Level of Assurance downgrade Attack
objects.description:
As a registered user, the attacker intercept the SAMLRequest
He or she tampers the response lowering the Level of Assurance present in the AuthnContextClassRef element contained as a sub-element of AuthContext of the AuthStatement.
The attacker sends the Response to the vulnerable SP
This attack decreases the level of Assurance requested by the SP in order to authenticate the user.
The attacker may be able to authenticate himself as a victim without possessing its second authentication factor (i.e a smartphone,…). The attacker may be able to authenticate himself without possessing as example the related smartphone used as second factor

external_references.url: SAML specification; SAML Profiles - 3.3

objects.name: Incorrect information flow between cryptographic and non-cryptographic components paving the way to Signature wrapping attacks
objects.description: Improper implementation of the assertion consumption procedure using different referencing schemes to locate paths of elements and assertions of SAML messages for the signature verification function and for the application logic.

external_references.url: https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/usenixsecurity12/sec12-final91.pdf

external_references.description: Sebastian Gajek, Meiko Jensen, Lijun Liao, and Jo ̈rg Schwenk - “Analysis of Signature Wrapping Attacks and Countermeasures”
Mercy Viola Akuleut - “Security Test Plan for SAML SSO 2.0 Implementations: The SPID Use Case”

objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Incorrect information flow between cryptographic and non-cryptographic components paving the way to Signature wrapping attacks
objects.description:
Several countermeasures in order to tackle the vulnerability from the SP side are the followings:
XML Schema validation: Response has to be validated against the applied SAML schemes to identify all the Id values and to reject messages with non unique Id (duplicated maliciously) or non SAML complaint messages 

Extract assertions: every assertion of the Response is extracted and saved as a separated DOM tree

Validate signature: the verification of every enveloped signature is exclusively done on the DOM tree of each assertion

Verify what is signed: in each assertion, the XML node addressed by the URI attribute of the Reference element is compared to the root element of the same assertion. If and only if both objects are identical, then the XML Signature in the assertion is an enveloped signature

Assertion processing: the subsequent assertion processing is solely done with the extracted and successfully validated assertions.

Same framework: the signature validation and the SAML assertion evaluation have to be dealt in a single framework using the same libraries and processing modules

Unsigned elements exclusion: excluding from the application logic module those unsigned elements that do not contain any signed descendant

Uniquely identifying the signed data: establishing a communication procedure between the signature verification function and the application logic by the use of XML node types which are visible to the XML processor and they do not violate the XML Signature.

external_references.url: https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/usenixsecurity12/sec12-final91.pdf

external_references.description: Sebastian Gajek, Meiko Jensen, Lijun Liao, and Jo ̈rg Schwenk - “Analysis of Signature Wrapping Attacks and Countermeasures”
Mercy Viola Akuleut - “Security Test Plan for SAML SSO 2.0 Implementations: The SPID Use Case”

objects.name: XML Signature Wrapping Attack
objects.description:
The attacker obtains a SAML assertion with a valid Signature.

An original element of the SAML message is moved within the document to a position unknown to the application logic. This location allows the element to not be processed by application logic, while the signature verification logic can still verify the element.

A new structurally corrected element is added at the original position, but has different content.

The signature verification function finds the original element and the signature remains valid because the content of the element is still not modified.

The application logic processes the new element located at the original position.

The attack is successful when the SP verifies the XML Signature but the application logic procedure processes the element with arbitrary parameters.
There can be different permutations of the attack based on the location of the original element, the faked element and the signature. Some of them are effective just in case the server does not check the SAML conformance:
Positioning the 3 elements on the same level

Locating them on three different levels

Using two levels 


In [7] are exposed 8 different variants of the attack exploiting several elements and positions of the SAML message.
This attack allows the modification or insertion of any value of parameters or elements.
The attacker can perform at any time any arbitrary web Service request by simply forging his own Response with values of a victim in order to impersonate him or login at a target SP. The attacker can perform arbitrary web Service requests while authenticating as a legitimate user.

external_references.url: SAML specification; SAML Profiles - 3.3

objects.name: Missing check on the presence of the Signature associated to SAML message
objects.description: The vulnerability consists in validating only signatures present, but skipping the validation whether the signature has been removed even if it is required

external_references.url: http://www.ws-attacks.org/XML_Signature_Exclusion

objects.x_FBK_vulnerabilityClass: Incorrect checks of SAML messages Class
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing implementation of controls to disable the acceptance of unsolicited SAML messages

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing check on the presence of the Signature associated to SAML message
objects.description:
In order to tackle effectively the vulnerability, the SP must:
make sure that a signature is required by the application and that exists in the SAML message 

validate every signature 

pay attention at the design and implementation of the flow of the validation steps

external_references.url: http://www.ws-attacks.org/XML_Signature_Exclusion

objects.name: XML Signature Exclusion Attack
objects.description:
Intercepting a SAML message
Removing all the signatures within the token 
Tamper the security elements or attributes
Given a successful attack, the messages can be freely edited.
An extremely severe further exploit consists in the the attacker creating his own token containing the identity of other users and thus gain access to other accounts.
An extremely severe further exploit makes the attacker create his own token containing the identity of other users and thus gain access to other accounts.

external_references.url: SAML specification; SAML Profiles - 3.3

objects.name: Missing check on the presence of the Signature associated to SAML message
objects.description: The vulnerability consists in validating only signatures present, but skipping the validation whether the signature has been removed even if it is required

objects.name: Missing SP field in Response
objects.description: The IdP generates the Response and the Assertion without inserting any reference about the SP that requested the AuthnRequest.

external_references.description: Alessandro Armando Roberto Carbone Luca Compagna Jorge Cuellar Llanos Tobarra - “Formal Analysis of SAML 2.0 Web Browser Single Sign-On/ Breaking the SAML-based Single Sign-On for Google Apps”

objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing SP field in Response
objects.description: Following the standard Core of SAML by OASIS, the Response and the Assertion must contain the SP field and its value must be the reference to the requestor SP

external_references.description: Alessandro Armando Roberto Carbone Luca Compagna Jorge Cuellar Llanos Tobarra - “Formal Analysis of SAML 2.0 Web Browser Single Sign-On/ Breaking the SAML-based Single Sign-On for Google Apps”

objects.name: Missing Recipient attribute in SubjectConfirmationData element of Assertion
objects.description: The IdP generates the Assertion without inserting the Recipient attribute inside the SubjectConfirmationData element. This Recipient must contain the value URL of the Assertion Consumer Service of the SP.
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing Recipient attribute in SubjectConfirmationData element of Assertion
objects.description: Following the standard Profile of SAML by OASIS, the Assertion must be implemented in order to contain the Recipient attribute inside the SubjectConfirmationData element.

objects.name: Missing Audience element inside AudienceRestriction element in Assertion
objects.description: The IdP generates the Assertion without inserting the Audience element inside the AudienceRestriction element. This Audience must contain the value URL of the Assertion Consumer Service.
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing Audience element inside AudienceRestriction element in Assertion
objects.description: Following the standard Profile of SAML by OASIS, the Assertion must be implemented in order to contain the Audience element inside the AudienceRestriction element.

objects.name: Missing InResponseTo element in Response
objects.description: The IdP generates the Response without inserting the InResponseTo. This element must contain the ID of the related AuthnRequest.
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing InResponseTo element in Response
objects.description: Following the standard Profile of SAML by OASIS, the Response must be implemented in order to contain the InResponseTo element whose value is the ID of the related SAML Request.

objects.name: Missing NotOnOrAfter attribute in Conditions and SubjectConfirmationData element of Assertion
objects.description: The IdP generates the Assertion without inserting the NotOnOrAfter attribute inside the SubjectConfirmationData and Conditions elements. This attribute must contain the time instant at which the subject can no longer be confirmed.
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing NotOnOrAfter attribute in Conditions and SubjectConfirmationData element of Assertion
objects.description: Following the standard Profile of SAML by OASIS, the Assertion must be implemented in order to contain the NotOnOrAfter attribute inside the SubjectConfirmationData and Condition elements. The value for NotBefore and NotOnOrAfter attributes should have the shortest validity period, typically on the order of a few minutes.

objects.name: Missing OneTimeUse element in Conditions element of Assertion
objects.description: The IdP generates the Assertion without inserting the OneTimeUse attribute inside the Conditions elements. This element indicates that it can be consumed just for a single time.
objects.x_FBK_vulnClass_description: All the vulnerabilities related to an improper or a missing generation of elements or parameters in SAML messages.

objects.name: Mitigations for Missing OneTimeUse element in Conditions element of Assertion
objects.description: The Assertion must be implemented in order to contain the OneTimeUse element inside the Conditions of the Assertion.
